title: 1000 Zeros
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"How many trailing  zeros are there in the expansion of 1000 factorial?"}]},{"type":"text","text":"\n\n"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1000 factorial is equal to  (1000!)"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Okay, there are 1000 ÷ 5 = 200 multiples of 5 between 1 and 1000. The next power of 5, namely 25, has 1000 ÷ 25 = 40 multiples between 1 and 1000. The next power of 5, namely 125, will also fit in the expansion, and has 1000 ÷ 125 = 8 multiples between 1 and 1000. The next power of 5, namely 625, also fits in the expansion, and has 1000 ÷ 625 = 1.6... um, okay, 625 has 1 multiple between 1 and 1000. (I don't care about the 0.6 "multiples", only the one full multiple, so I truncate my division down to a whole number.)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"In total, I have 200 + 40 + 8 + 1 = 249 copies of the factor 5 in the expansion, and thus:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"249 trailing zeroes in the expansion of 1000!"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"-You have $100 to buy 100 animals. If:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"bulletList","content":[{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A Cow cost $10"}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A Pig cost $3"}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A Fish cost $0.5"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(Buy at least one of each)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Assuming:","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"bulletList","content":[{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"text","text":"C","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" Is the number of Cows"}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"text","text":"P","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" Is the number of Pigs"}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"text","text":"F","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" Is the number of Fish"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"What is te value of: "},{"type":"text","text":"F + P - C","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"How many 3 digit numbers are there, such that the hundreds digit is strictly smaller than the tens digit, which is strictly smaller than the units digit?"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Can you solve this without listing?"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Continued from ...","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since the hundreds digit cannot be "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and must be the smallest digit, we know that the "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"-digit numbers cannot have any "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"'s."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now for any three distinct digit chosen from the set "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\{1,2,3,4,5,6,7,8,9\}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" there is only one way to arrange them in strictly ascending order, and there is one-to-one correspondence between digits chosen in this manner and the "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"-digit numbers we are wanting to count. Thus the desired solution is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\dbinom{9}{3} = \boxed{84}."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

replies.body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":" @Chung Kevin – "}],"attrs":[{"profile":""}]},{"type":"text","text":" You're right: for some reason I remembered it as being a bit harder. I guess I was thinking of counting the number of, say, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"-digit numbers whose digits were in (not strictly) ascending order. The method is still the same as the one I posted in your next problem, but it does get quite tedious."}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Edit: At the prompting of Calvin, I found that there is a "simple" solution for (not strictly ascending) "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"-digit numbers in general, which I've outlined in a comment under the solution I posted to your next question. "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            I believe that it's still just as "easy". You just have to find the correct bijection. "},{"type":"text","text":"Here is the question","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"In the "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 10 \leq 1 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" case, the answer is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 45 = {1  0 \choose 2 } "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            My pleasure. :) If the order were strictly descending then we would have to bring "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" back into play. Both problems would then become quite a bit harder if the order were no longer "strict".

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"

                                            Great! Thanks for highlighting this approach. In the previous question, most people did it the tedious way of listing out every case.

replies.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Oh it's another way to write 9C3. Great, really conscientious. Thanks.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            The number of combinations of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"r"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" items chosen from a set of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" distinct items is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\dbinom{n}{r} = \dfrac{n!}{r!(n - r)!}."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"In this case we have "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n = 9, r = 3,"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" with "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\dbinom{9}{3} = \dfrac{9!}{3!*6!} = \dfrac{9*8*7}{6} = 3*4*7 = 84."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"

replies.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Yes, that's the idea. The question is then how does one most efficiently count all such 3-digit numbers, which is why I took the approach that I did and not count them case by case.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            I feel like I'm misunderstanding the question. If I have a 9 in the unit position, then I can have 2 thru 8 in the tens position. If it is a 2 in the tens position, then I can only have a 1 in the hundreds position. If it is an 8 in the tens position, then I can have 1 thru 7 in the hundreds position. Or not?

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"codeBlock","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 1
 2
 3
 4
 5
 6

 8
 9
10
11
12ctr = 0
for i in range(100,1000):
    ones = i%10
    i /= 10
    tens = i%10
    i /= 10
    hund = i
    if ones>tens:
        if tens>hund:
            ctr += 1

print ctr 


"}],"attrs":[{"text":"ctr = 0
for i in range(100,1000):
    ones = i%10
    i /= 10
    tens = i%10
    i /= 10
    hund = i
    if ones>tens:
        if tens>hund:
            ctr += 1

print ctr 
","language":null}]},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":""}]},{"type":"text","text":"

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since the hundreds digit cannot be zero and must be the smallest digit, we know that the 3-digit numbers cannot have any zeroes. The set of numbers from which we can make 3-digit numbers is therefor {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9}."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"To fill the three places (without repetition), we can pick from 9 numbers, then from 8 numbers, and finally from 7 numbers. The total number of 3-digit numbers therefor is 9 x 8 x 7 = 504. But these do not contain only numbers that are ascending."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let's say we pick three random distinct numbers from our set. For example, 2, 1, and 6. How many 3-digit numbers can we make with only those numbers? Well, 3 x 2 x 1 = 6:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"table","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"tableRow","content":[{"type":"tableCell","content":[{"type":"text","text":"162"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"tableRow","content":[{"type":"tableCell","content":[{"type":"text","text":"216"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"tableRow","content":[{"type":"tableCell","content":[{"type":"text","text":"261"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"tableRow","content":[{"type":"tableCell","content":[{"type":"text","text":"612"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"tableRow","content":[{"type":"tableCell","content":[{"type":"text","text":"126"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"tableRow","content":[{"type":"tableCell","content":[{"type":"text","text":"621"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"
"}]},{"type":"text","text":"
"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Notice that only one of them is ascending, 126. We need to eliminate 6 answers we're not looking for and that leaves us with the correct answer, 1. In other words, divide 6 by 6 to get 1."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For every 3-digit number in the 504 3-digit numbers, there are 6 versions of it, but in a different order. We need to get rid of those. In other words, divide 504 by 6 to get 84."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}
